If that enemy is evil, she gets a free reroll on any failed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls against that target for the remainder of the encounter. She may use this ability once per Rank per encounter.

requirements.label: Vow (Minor or Major - serve their deity or order)

Pathfinder Chronicler.name: Pathfinder Chronicler
Pathfinder Chronicler.description:
Brave explorers and seekers of lost or forgotten knowledge, these heroes are quintessential adventurers. They travel the world searching for esoteric truths, magical and mundane relics, and unexplored vistas.

Pathfinding: The pathfinder increases the party’s speed by 10% when navigating to known or mapped locations. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{Travel}.

She also knows which paths are safest and where to exercise additional caution. If the Game Master is drawing for encounters and gets the Enemies result (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{Travel}), the chronicler may make a Smarts roll at −2 to discard that card and replace it with the next card in the deck.

Pathfinder Chronicler II.name: Pathfinder Chronicler II
Pathfinder Chronicler II.description: Epic Tales: The chronicler recites a moving and evocative tale. Once per session, while the party is resting, every Wild Card ally who hears the tale gains a Benny.

Pathfinder Chronicler III.name: Pathfinder Chronicler III
Pathfinder Chronicler III.description:
Call Down the Legends: Once per game week, the chronicler can magically summon five “shades” of great Golarion heroes who have gone before. The shades assume mortal form, have the profiles in the sidebar at right, and last for one hour.

Shades

The shades appear as silent, somewhat formless heroes of Golarion— elves, dwarves, humans, and others. They cannot be mistaken for living beings except in the most obscured conditions. They appear from darkness and vanish into it when their time on the mortal realm expires. They are physical while here, and have only a fraction of their true self’s abilities.

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} d6, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} d8, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} d6, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} d4, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 8 (2)

Hindrances: —

Edges: —

Gear: Leather armor (+2), long sword (Str+d8).

Special Abilities:

  • Construct: +2 to recover from being Shaken; don’t breathe; immune to poison and disease.
  • Fearless: Shades are immune to Fear and Intimidation.

Power Points.name: Power Points
Power Points.description: Wizards, sorcerers, and other arcane types always want more power. This Edge grants them an additional 5 Power Points. Power Points may be selected more than once, but only once per Rank. It may be taken as often as desired at Legendary Rank, but each grants only 2 additional points.

Power Surge.name: Power Surge
Power Surge.description: The character recovers 10 Power Points when his Action Card is a Joker. This may not exceed his usual limit.

Powerful Blow.name: Powerful Blow
Powerful Blow.description: The barbarian's savage @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attacks} cause +4 damage instead of +2.

Professional.name: Professional
Professional.description: The character is an expert at a particular skill or attribute (his choice). This increases the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Trait} and its limit one step (a d12+1 becomes a d12+2, for example). This Edge may be selected once per Trait.

requirements.label: maximum die type possible in affected Trait

Provoke.name: Provoke
Provoke.description:
Clever characters can manipulate their foes, drawing enemy focus on themselves to protect their allies. Once per turn, when your hero uses Taunt for a Test and gets a raise (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Test}), she may Provoke the foe.

In addition to all the usual effects of the success and raise, the enemy suffers a −2 penalty to affect any other target besides the one who provoked her. This stacks with Distracted but not further instances of Provoke.

Provoke lasts until a Joker is drawn, someone else Provokes the target, or the encounter ends. Provoke may be combined with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Rabble-Rouser]{Rabble Rouser}.

Quarry.name: Quarry
Quarry.description:
The ranger's expertise expands to include additional enemies and terrain. Choose an additional enemy and terrain type for your Favored Enemy and Favored Terrain abilities.

This Edge may be taken once per Rank.

Quick.name: Quick
Quick.description:
Quick characters have lightning-fast reflexes and a cool head. Whenever you are dealt an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Action Card} of Five or lower, you may discard it and draw again until you get a card higher than Five.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01makingcharac00]{Characters} with both the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Level Headed]{Level Headed} and Quick Edges first draw their additional card and choose which to take. If that card is a Five or less, the Quick Edge may be used to draw a replacement until it’s Six or higher.

Rabble-Rouser.name: Rabble-Rouser
Rabble-Rouser.description: This instigator knows how to rile up several enemies at once. As a limited action, a character with this Edge can make a social Test with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} against all enemies in a Medium Blast Template. The targets must be able to see and hear the hero clearly. Each defender resists and is affected by the Test separately.

Ranger.name: Ranger
Ranger.description:
For those who relish the thrill of the hunt, there are only predators and prey. From scouts, to trackers, or bounty hunters, all rangers share the predator’s perspective. They value skill with weapons. They excel at stalking even the most elusive game. They train relentlessly to defeat a wide range of quarries.

Knowledgeable, patient, and skilled hunters, rangers pursue man, beast, and monster alike. While some track dangerous creatures to protect the frontier, others pursue more cunning game— even fugitives— into and through the dangerous wilds.

  • Armor Restriction (Medium): Rangers are agile and mobile fighters and scouts. They subtract 4 from Agility and Agility-based skill rolls when wearing heavy armor or using a heavy shield.
  • Favored Enemy: Rangers study their foes, learning their ways, how to find them, and how to defeat them. Choose a type of enemy from the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08bestiary000000]{Bestiary}. The ranger gets one free reroll when failing to track (Survival) or attack (Athletics (throwing), Fighting, Shooting) that type of being.
  • Favored terrain: Choose a terrain type (Arctic, Desert, Forest, Jungle, Plains, Hills/Mountains, Rivers/Seas, Swamp, Urban, or Underground). The ranger draws an additional Action Card for initiative when in his Favored Terrain. (This has no effect on the number of cards a Ranger can use, so a Level Headed character can still choose which card to use, while a Hesitant character must still take the worst card.)
  • Wilderness Stride: Rangers pass through rough terrain such as dense forest, rocky hills, or desert sands with ease. They ignore movement penalties for Difficult Ground (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Movement}).

Rapid Reload.name: Rapid Reload
Rapid Reload.description:
The warrior reduces the Reload value of a ranged weapon by 1. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reload}. This is most often taken for archers using crossbows with a Reload of 1 or 2. Weapons with Reload 1 may be reloaded as a free action with this Edge.

A character with this Edge may use Rapid Shot with a weapon if its Reload value has been reduced to a free action.

Rapid Shot.name: Rapid Shot
Rapid Shot.description:
The shooter is practiced at taking quick and accurate shots. When she’s armed with a weapon that can be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reloaded} as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}, and has enough arrows to do so, she may increase her weapon’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Rate of Fire} by 1 for any one of her @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} attacks that turn.

Rapid Shot may be used with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Rapid Reload]{Rapid Reload}.

Reliable.name: Reliable
Reliable.description: People know they can depend on your hero when they need assistance. He gets a free reroll on any @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Support} roll.

Retort.name: Retort
Retort.description:
This verbal duelist can turn the slings and arrows of social combat right back at the unwitting fools who hurled them.

If a character with Retort gets a raise when resisting an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} Test, the foe is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted}.

Rogue.name: Rogue
Rogue.description:
Life is an endless adventure for those who live by their wits. Ever just one step ahead of danger, rogues bank on their cunning, skill, and charm to bend fate to their favor. Never knowing what to expect, they tend to prepare for everything. Out of necessity, they become adept manipulators, agile acrobats, or shadowy stalkers. They are thieves and gamblers, fast talkers and diplomats, bandits and bounty hunters, or explorers and investigators.

Although many rogues favor the opportunities of towns and cities, some embrace life on the road. They wander from place to place, meeting exotic people and facing fantastic danger in pursuit of endless riches. In the end, all rogues desire to shape their fates and live life on their own terms.

  • Armor Restriction (Light): Rogues are nimble and deadly acrobats. Bulky armor interferes with their abilities, so they subtract 4 from Agility and Agility-based skill rolls when wearing medium or heavy armor, or using medium or heavy shields.
  • Sneak Attack: Rogues add an additional d6 to their damage when they have the Drop on their victim, or the victim is Vulnerable. This applies to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} attacks.

Scavenger.name: Scavenger
Scavenger.description:
Once per encounter the hero may find, “suddenly remember,” or dig up some much-needed piece of equipment, a quiver half-full of arrows, or some other useful device.

The Game Master decides what constitutes an encounter, and has the final word on what can and can’t be found.

Scholar.name: Scholar
Scholar.description:
Learned professors, devoted students, and amateur enthusiasts spend great amounts of time and energy studying particular subjects. They become experts in these fields, and rarely fail to answer questions in their particular area of expertise.

Pick any one of the following skills: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Academics]{Academics}, Battle, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Occult]{Occult}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Science]{Science}, or a Smarts-based “knowledge”-type skill allowed in your game, and add +2 to the total whenever they’re used.

This Edge may be taken more than once if applied to different skills.

Shadowdancer.name: Shadowdancer
Shadowdancer.description:
Some characters prefer the shadows, embracing the advantages of darkness to become artists of deception and surprise.

Greater Darkvision: Strong connection to the plane of shadows allows the hero to see perfectly in any illumination up to 10" (20 yards), including magical darkness and ignoring all penalties resulting from it.

Shadowdancer II.name: Shadowdancer II
Shadowdancer II.description: Shadow Cloak: Darkness envelops and protects its champion. She gets one free Soak attempt at −2 whenever she's Wounded in Dim or Dark Illumination. This does not count as spending a Benny.

Shadowdancer III.name: Shadowdancer III
Shadowdancer III.description:
Mystic Powers (Shadow Force): As a limited free action the shadowdancer can cast one of the following spells: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Teleport]{teleport} (self only). All of these have a Shadow Trapping.

The shadowdancer has 10 dedicated Power Points that @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{recharge} normally. She automatically activates the power with success for its regular cost, or with a raise for an additional 2 Power Points. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000000]{Powers} for more information on specific spells. She may use applicable Power Modifiers if desired (at the usual cost).

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast} still requires line of sight, but otherwise automatically hits as long as any part of the target is visible and in Range.

Mystic Powers doesn’t grant access to Edges requiring an Arcane Background. If the shadowdancer also has an Arcane Background, none of its Edges and abilities can be used with Mystic Powers (and vice-versa).

Sidekick.name: Sidekick
Sidekick.description:
A character who triumphs over evil time and time again becomes an inspiration to others. Eventually, one of these young crusaders may attempt to join the hero in his epic quests.

The hero gains a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Novice Rank} sidekick. The sidekick is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}, starts each session with two @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Bennies}, may @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01advancement000]{Advance}, and has abilities that complement his mentor. The player character controls his sidekick just like any other ally, though he may occasionally cause trouble by getting captured, running into danger when he’s not supposed to, and so on. The player should be prepared for his Edge to occasionally become a Hindrance!

If the sidekick dies, he isn’t replaced unless the hero chooses this Edge again. Fortunately, heroes may always spend Bennies for their sidekicks as if she had the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Common Bond]{Common Bond} Edge. Sidekicks must actually take that Edge to do the same for their mentors.

Soldier.name: Soldier
Soldier.description:
Professional soldiers get used to carrying heavy loads and enduring harsh conditions. After a few days getting used to their gear (GM’s call), they treat their Strength as one die type higher when determining @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Encumbrance} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Minimum Strength} to use armor, weapons, and equipment without a penalty. (This stacks with the Brawny Edge.)

They also get a free reroll on Vigor rolls made to survive environmental hazards (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}).

This Edge has no effect on Armor Interference or Armor Restriction.

Sorcerer.name: Sorcerer
Sorcerer.description:
Scions of magical bloodlines, pawns of fate and destiny, or simply flukes of fickle magic, sorcerers look within themselves for arcane prowess. As they tap into powers few mortals can imagine, these magic-touched souls must learn to harness the power of their birthright.

While some seek to control their abilities, others give in to their magic, letting it rule their lives. Sorcerers live and breathe that which other spellcasters devote their lives to mastering. For them magic is more than a useful tool or a field of study; it is life itself.

  • Arcane Background (Sorcerer): Sorcerers use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} as their arcane skill, but it is linked to Spirit instead of Smarts (if multiclassing as a Smarts-based spellcaster, use the better of the two Attributes). Soul Drain.name: Soul Drain
Soul Drain.description: Once per day, Soul Drain allows a character to take a level of Fatigue to recover up to five Power Points as a limited free action. Or she can take two levels of Fatigue (Exhaustion) to recover up to 10 Power Points. She cannot render herself @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} in this way.

Steady Hands.name: Steady Hands
Steady Hands.description:
Firing from the back of a horse or moving platform is tricky business, but your adventurer has figured it out. She ignores the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Unstable Platform} penalty.

This also helps when running, reducing the usual penalty from −2 to −1 (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Movement}).

Streetwise.name: Streetwise
Streetwise.description:
Streetwise characters know how to find the local black market, fence stolen goods, avoid the local law (or criminal element!), lay low when the heat’s on, obtain illegal weapons, find out which “boss” is hiring muscle, or similar shady activities.

Streetwise characters add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls made to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04networking0000]{Network} with shady or criminal elements. They also add +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} rolls pertaining to the types of disreputable activities listed above.

Strength Surge.name: Strength Surge
Strength Surge.description: The barbarian’s rage knows no bounds! Her Strength increases two die types when raging instead of just one. This can exceed the character’s ancestral limit.

Strong Willed.name: Strong Willed
Strong Willed.description: Self-confidence is powerful armor against those who attempt to attack this individual’s will. He adds +2 to his total when resisting Tests with Smarts or Spirit.

Sweep.name: Sweep
Sweep.description:
Some heroes are able to face down multiple enemies at once.

As a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{limited action}, Sweep allows a character to make a single Fighting attack with a two-handed weapon and apply it against all targets in his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach} at a −2 penalty (friends and foes alike). Resolve damage separately for each enemy that’s hit.

Note: Some creatures have the Sweep Edge even though they don't have two handed weapons. In their case their size, lanky limbs, or other advantages allow them to make Sweep attacks.

Tactician.name: Tactician
Tactician.description:
The commander has a natural grasp of small unit tactics and can take advantage of rapidly changing situations.

A Tactician is dealt an extra Action Card each round of combat— kept separate from his own cards. At the start of the round, he may discard it or give it to any one allied Extra in Command Range. The player or GM controlling the receiving character can decide whether to accept and replace her current Action Card, or discard it.

Surprise: Tacticians don’t get their extra card if Surprised, but they can give it to an ally who’s Surprised if they like!

Thief.name: Thief
Thief.description:
Thieves specialize in deceit, treachery, and acrobatics. They can be invaluable where traps must be detected, walls must be climbed, and locks must be picked.

Thieves know how to use the slimmest protrusions on walls and window ledges to climb the tallest of buildings, scampering through streets and back alleys like cats. They add +1 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} rolls made to climb in urban areas.

Thieves also know how to use the dark areas between the streetlights of cities to conceal their movements, and add +1 to Stealth rolls when in an urban environment.

Finally, these rogues are— not surprisingly—
adept at Thievery itself, adding +1 to those rolls in all circumstances.

Tough As Nails.name: Tough As Nails
Tough As Nails.description: Your character keeps going when others fall. She can take four @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} before she’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} (her maximum Wound penalty is still −3).

Tougher Than Nails.name: Tougher Than Nails
Tougher Than Nails.description: The hero can take up to five @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} before she’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}! Her maximum Wound penalty is still −3.

Trademark Weapon.name: Trademark Weapon
Trademark Weapon.description:
The hero knows one unique weapon (Excalibur, Old Betsy, Sting) like the back of his hand. When using it, he adds +1 to his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls, and +1 to Parry when readied (even if it’s a ranged weapon).

A fighter can take this Edge multiple times, applying it to a different weapon each time. If a Trademark Weapon is lost, he can replace it but the benefits don’t kick in for a few days (however long the GM feels is dramatically appropriate).

requirements.label: skill with chosen weapon of d8+

Trap Sense.name: Trap Sense
Trap Sense.description:
Rogues are adept at spotting and defeating all but the most clever snares and traps. They get a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} roll anytime a detectable trap is about to be sprung within 5” (10 yards). They must have line of sight to the trap and can’t be Shaken or Stunned. This works generally like Danger Sense but applies only to mechanical and magical traps.

Traps are fully described @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{here}.

If the trap is detected and may be Evaded, the rogue and anyone she warns ignores 2 points of Evasion penalties to do so. If the trap can’t normally be Evaded, anyone warned may Evade at the usual −2 penalty.

Disarming Traps: Rogues with Trap Sense ignore up 2 points of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Thievery]{Thievery} penalties when attempting to disarm traps.

Troubadour.name: Troubadour
Troubadour.description: Troubadours travel the world, learning culture, etiquette, history, and above all, legends. They add +2 to Common Knowledge rolls and may use Performance in place of Battle for Leadership Edges or Edges that require Battle.

Two-Weapon Fighting.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
Two-Weapon Fighting.description:
If a character makes an attack with one action and another from a different hand in a later action, the second attack doesn’t inflict a Multi-Action penalty. The Off-Hand penalty still applies unless he’s @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Ambidextrous]{Ambidextrous}, however.

The character can choose to make a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} attack with each hand, an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) attack with each hand, or a combination of these, depending on the readied weapons.

Uncanny Reflexes.name: Uncanny Reflexes
Uncanny Reflexes.description: The rogue has an uncanny ability to avoid area attacks and effects. She ignores the usual −2 Agility penalty when making @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Evasion} attempts. She also gets a regular Evasion attempt against area effect attacks or effects that don’t usually allow it (at the usual −2 penalty) such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burst]{burst} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{blast}, or even @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Confusion]{confusion} or similar spells cast with the Area Effect modifier.

Very Attractive.name: Very Attractive
Very Attractive.description: Your hero is drop-dead gorgeous. He increases his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance} and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} bonus to +2.

Weapon Master.name: Weapon Master
Weapon Master.description: The warrior increases his @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01makingcharac00]{Parry} by +1 and the bonus damage die for @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls is a d8 instead of a d6 (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Bonus Damage}). He must be armed to gain these benefits, but this includes the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Martial Artist]{Martial Artist} Edge, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08specialabili00]{claws}, or other abilities that count as weapons.

Wholeness of Body.name: Wholeness of Body
Wholeness of Body.description: The monk may spend 2 Power Points to make a Soak roll. This does not count as spending a Benny.

Wild Shape.name: Wild Shape
Wild Shape.description: The druid gains the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Shape Change]{shape change} spell, if she doesn’t already have it. The Duration is one hour for her, and she casts as if she were one Rank higher than her actual Rank on the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Shape Change]{shape change} table.

Wizard.name: Wizard
Wizard.description:
Beyond the veil of the mundane hide the secrets of absolute power. Mysteries, and wonders of arcane realms call to those with the ambition—and the intellect—to grasp true power. Such is the path of the wizard.

These magic-users research, collect, and covet esoteric knowledge. Some choose to become a master of a particular field of magic. Others embrace versatility, reveling in the unbounded wonders of all magic. In either case, wizards prove a cunning lot, capable of smiting their foes, empowering their allies, and shaping the world to their every desire.

  • Arcane Background (Wizard):Wizards use @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} as their arcane skill. A hero who takes this @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edgesummarie00]{Edge} gains 10 @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Power Points]{Power Points} and three powers from the list below.   • Arcane Bond: Wizards form an intense magical bond with an object or creature. See Arcane Bond, below.
  • Armor Interference (any): Like sorcerers, wizards must gesticulate in precise patterns. They subtract 4 from their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} rolls and from their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} and Agility-based skill rolls if using light, medium, or heavy @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{armor} or shields.
  • School: A wizard’s studies lead him down one of two paths—the “universalist” who dabbles in all the various “schools” of magic, or a “specialist” who focuses on one school at the expense of some others.

Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{Schools of Magic}. They gain a free @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{reroll} on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Power Points]{Power Point} and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll. Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*

  • Spellbooks Wizards must keep and maintain spellbooks (see wizard class edge in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{edges}

ARCANE BOND

Wizards immerse themselves in the study of eldritch lore and arcane theories. During these long hours they form a bond with a dependable item or friendly creature (a “familiar”). Choose one of the following options for your wizard:

  • Bonded Object: The spellcaster possesses an amulet, ring, staff, wand, or weapon that adds +1 to all his @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{Spellcasting} totals when worn or in hand. If the object is lost or destroyed, the mage can replace it with a new object worth at least 500 gp.
  • Familiar: The mage has a magical pet. See the familiars sidebar in the wizard class edge section @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{here}.

Woodsman.name: Woodsman
Woodsman.description:
Woodsmen are rangers, scouts, and hunters who are more at home in the wilderness than urban areas. They are skilled trackers and scouts, and know how to live off the land for months at a time.

Woodsmen add +2 to Survival and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Stealth]{Stealth} rolls made in the wild (not towns, ruins, or underground).

Work the Crowd.name: Work the Crowd
Work the Crowd.description: As @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Work The Room]{Work the Room} but the hero now can Support another on up to two of her Support actions.

Work the Room.name: Work the Room
Work the Room.description: Your hero’s words don’t just inspire those they’re directed at— they often inspire others as well. Once per turn, you can use Work the Room to roll an additional skill die when Supporting with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Performance]{Performance}. The additional die Supports any other ally who can see or hear your hero, and applies to their next action, whatever it may be.
